assessment_steps.description: The paper establishes a clear link between LRRK2 kinase activity and Parkinson's disease (PD). Mutations affecting kinase activity (e.g., G2019S) are directly tied to PD pathogenesis.
The KESTREL screen and kinase activity assays are directly relevant to the disease mechanism (kinase activity modulates PD risk).
The study uses wild-type and mutant controls (e.g., G2019S vs. non-pathogenic variants) and reports experiments conducted in triplicate.
Known pathogenic variants (e.g., G2019S) and benign variants (e.g., R1441C) are used as controls in the assays.
The study uses 8 control variants (4 pathogenic/inhibitory, 4 neutral). Since this is <11, the strength is Max PS3_supporting.
LRRK2 kinase activity modulates PD risk, and mutations affecting activity (e.g., R1941H) are tied to pathogenesis.
Kinase activity assays are directly relevant to the disease mechanism.
The study uses wild-type and mutant controls and replicates experiments.
Known pathogenic variants (e.g., R1941H) and benign variants are used as controls.
The study uses 8 control variants (4 pathogenic/inhibitory, 4 neutral). Since this is <11, the strength is Max PS3_supporting.
